p: The comparative analysis of parasitic and nonparasitic members of Convolvulaceae seed germination showed slower germination in the parasitic plants, further delayed by salinity ( Figure 1), which is in conformity with the existing literature. The strategy of nonparasitic vines involves fast initial growth and climbing over other plants to outcompete surrounding species [ 32]. The relatively big seeds of these species germinated as fast as possible ( Figure 1dâ€“f), mobilizing starch by activation of amylases ( Figure 4). In contrast, even when physical dormancy was artificially broken (through scarification), germination in Cuscuta spp. was slower.
